description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the Giraffe.
title: All About the Giraffe

slides.title: Introduction to the Giraffe
slides.content: The giraffe (Giraffa camelopardalis) is the tallest living terrestrial animal and the largest ruminant. Native to Africa, giraffes are known for their extremely long neck and legs, which give them a distinctive silhouette and the ability to reach vegetation inaccessible to other herbivores.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Giraffes can reach heights of up to 18 feet and weigh up to 2,800 pounds, with males being larger than females.
Their neck alone can be 6-7 feet long and contains the same number of vertebrae as most mammals (seven), but each is greatly elongated.

slides.title: Feeding and Behavior
content: Giraffes are herbivores that feed mainly on leaves, flowers, and fruits from the tops of trees, particularly acacia trees.
They have a specialized tongue that can be up to 18-20 inches long, colored blue-black to protect against sunburn while feeding.

slides.title: Social Structure and Communication
content: Giraffes live in loose social groups that are constantly changing, with no fixed leadership or territorial behavior.
They communicate using infrasound (low-frequency sounds below human hearing range) and through various body postures and movements.

slides.title: Conservation and Habitat
content: Giraffes inhabit savannas, grasslands, and open woodlands across sub-Saharan Africa, though their populations have declined significantly.
They are vulnerable to extinction due to habitat loss, poaching, and civil unrest in some regions where they live.
